spans.content: TaiZhe Lin, BaoTao Kang, MinHwan Jeon, Craig Huffman, JeaHoo Jeon, SungJoo Lee, Wei Han, JinYong Lee, SeHan Lee, GeunYoung Yeom, \*, and KyongNam Kim\*
Department of Advanced Materials Science and Engineering, Sungkyunkwan University, Suwon 440- 746, Korea
SKKU Advanced Institute of Nano Technology (SAINT), Sungkyunkwan University, Suwon 440- 746, Korea
SEMATECH, 257 Fuller Road, Suite 2200, Albany, New York 12203, United States
Department of Physics, Jilin University, Changchun, Province of Jilin China
Department of Chemistry, Sungkyunkwan University, Suwon 440- 746, Korea
ABSTRACT: Two- dimensional (2D) metal dichalcogenides like molybdenum disulfide

may provide a pathway to high- mobility channel materials that are needed for beyond- complementary metal- oxide- semiconductor (CMOS) devices. Controlling the thickness of these materials at the atomic level will be a key factor in the future development of
devices. In this study, we propose a layer- by- layer removal of
using the atomic layer etching (ALET) that is composed of the cyclic processing of chlorine (Cl)- radical adsorption and argon
etching was not observed with only the Cl- radical adsorption or low- energy
ion- beam desorption steps; however, the use of sequential
etching that is composed of the Cl- radical adsorption step and a subsequent
ion- beam desorption step resulted in the complete etching of one monolayer of
. Raman spectroscopy, X- ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), and atomic force microscopy (AFM) indicated the removal of one monolayer of
with each ALET cycle; therefore, the number of
layers could be precisely controlled by using this cyclical etch method. In addition, no noticeable damage or etch residue was observed on the exposed
, atomic layer etching, layer by layer etching, two- dimensional (2D) material, adsorption, desorption, plasma
is a typical layer- structured composite metal dichalcogenide composed of a

crystal structure and is one of the newly investigated twodimensional (2D) electronic materials that is similar to graphene.1- 7 van der Waals force is dominant between the layers, while covalent bonds control the interaction within the layers.8- 12
is a semiconducting material, and different band gap energies have been found for different numbers of
layers. As the layers of material decrease, the band gap is enhanced from 1.29 to

a monolayer is due to the quantum confinement effect). At the same time, with a decrease of the number of layers, a tendency from the indirect gap to the direct gap is observed between the conduction band and the valence band.
has a stable crystal structure, does not react with strong acids, and has an electron mobility that can reach
- monolayer field- effect transistors that have been fabricated with hafnium(IV) oxide
as the gate dielectric show a current on/off ratio as high as
at room temperature and a very low standby- power dissipation; therefore, it can be used in the fabrication of 2D
is smaller than that of an Si crystal structure, and the mass of

is lighter than the Si crystal structure when it obtains the same electron- mobility effect. At a steady state, the energy consumption is known to be lower than that of traditional Si transistors.14 Moreover,
is investigated as a promising material for hydrogen evolution,15 transistors,16,17 and sensors,18 in addition to flexible electronics due to a high Young's modulus of approximately 33 TPa.19

The electronic properties of 2D materials and their application strongly depend on the number of layers; therefore, a simple and efficient method to control thickness is necessary. The chemical vapor deposition (CVD) method is widely investigated regarding the growth of large- area
but currently, it is difficult to control the layers of
especially for a low layer number, with this method. At present, only
flake obtained by exfoliation have a proven reliability.13,17
layers can be controlled by removing the layers after synthesis. Recently, the use of argon
plasma to conduct the layer- by- layer etching of
has been investigated by Liu et al., and the results showed the possibility of using sputter etching to achieve a monolayer
; however, their etching process resulted in physical damage to the sample surface, as detected by Raman spectroscopy.
layer thickness by using xerom difluoride
etching, which formed volatile etch products such as molybdenum hexafluoride
Castellanos- Gomez et al. reported the use of a laser thinning technique on a multilayer
film to achieve a monolayer, but this method showed drawbacks such as thermal damage to the bottom layer.
Thermal- annealing and oxygen- treatment methods have also been reported as approaches that can thin
On the basis of an analysis of all of the currently reported techniques, however, the removed
depth can only be controlled by etch time, and a precise control of the number of
layers at the atomic scale cannot be achieved.

Previously, in the etching of various semiconducting materials, the atomic layer etching technique (ALET) has shown promising results for next- generation devices due to characteristics such as precise atomic- scale control of the etch depth, extreme uniformity over a large wafer area, and low levels of damage and contamination.
In this research, we propose the ALET as a precise layer- by- layer etching technique for
material. Using ALET, we investigated the possibility of removing one monolayer of
through the chemical absorption and physical desorption of the cyclic reaction. Also, the possibility of obtaining one monolayer of
formation without inducing damage and contamination on the remaining

layers that had been synthesized using the CVD method (shown in Figure S1 in Supporting Information) were etched layer by layer using a two- step ALET. First, chlorine radicals that were generated from an inductively coupled plasma (ICP) system were adsorbed onto the
surface was removed using a low- energy
During Cl- radical adsorption, ion bombardment was significantly reduced by installing a grounded, metal mesh grid between the ICP source and the substrate. The
plasma for adsorption was generated with 63 sccm of
pressure. For the desorption step, the samples were transferred to a dual- grid
ion- beam system. The process conditions were 70 sccm of
ICP power, and 6.7 mTorr pressure. An extraction grid voltage of between
V was used to accelerate the
ion, while the outside grid of the ion- beam system was grounded. (For schematic diagrams of the ICP systems used for the adsorption of the Cl radical and the
ion- beam system used to desorb the chemisorbed
layer, see Figure S2, (a) and (b).) The ion flux and energy distribution of the
ion beam were measured using a quadruple mass spectrometer with an ion energy analyzer (Hiden Analytical Ltd., EQP1000) that was located close to the sample location (shown in Figure S2, (b)).
layers before and after the layer- by- layer etching were estimated using Raman spectroscopy (WITEC 2000, 532 nm wavelength, installed with a grating of 1800 grooves/m and a spectral center of
). The thickness was determined by measuring the shift of the Raman peaks at the
was also measured using atomic force microscopy (AFM, INOVA microscope by Bruker) and a sample patterned by photoresist; the photoresist was removed before the
measurement with AFM. The chemical binding states of the
surface before and after the Cl- radical adsorption and before and after the
ion desorption were observed using X- ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS, Thermo VG, Multilab 2000).

In addition to Raman spectroscopy, the change of the
layer during the ALET cycles was measured using AFM. For this measurement, a trilayer

film was masked with photoresist and exposed to one and two ALET cycles. The photoresist was removed by acetone, and the step was measured using AFM. Figure 6a) and Figure 6b show the AFM data after a single cycle of ALET for the monolayer
and two cycles of ALET for the trilayer

The big step heights at the boundary (two bright lines on the optical microscopic picture) are due to the photoresist residue remaining even after the photoresist removal to measure the etch step after two ALET cycles.

that relate to the orbital binding energy of Mo

or the oxidized Mo particle on the

ion- desorption step, indicating that the Cl adsorption on the
during the radical- adsorption step was removed during the

In the XPS narrow- scan data of Mo in Figure 7a, an additional peak at
is also shown and it remains until the Cl- adsorption step of the third ALET cycle. We found that this peak is related to the 2D

(see Figure S4). In the case of S, when the

structure was not removed, and no peak
ion- desorption step of the third ALET cycle. Also, a decrease of the S
peak was not found until the third ALET cycle. It is therefore believed that by using this ALET, a multilayer
can be etched precisely layer- by- layer without noticeably damaging the exposed
We have demonstrated that the thickness of a multilayer
can be controlled layer- by- layer using Cl- radical adsorption and
ion desorption in accordance with the ALET. Raman spectra, AFM data, and XPS data suggest that one monolayer of

can be etched with one ALET cycle; therefore, the precise control of the etch layer can presumably be achieved using the ALET. Moreover, no Cl residue and no noticeable damage were found on the remaining
underlayer after each ALET cycle. We believe that this ALET method can also be applicable when precisely controlling the layers of other 2D materials such as
; therefore, it can be utilized as a useful engineering tool for controlling the properties of next- generation 2D devices without inducing residue and damage.

Figures showing CVD system, ICP system, microscope pictures and Raman spectra, and XPS data. The Supporting Information is available free of charge on the ACS Publications website at DOI: 10.1021/acsami.5b03491.
